thread.title: The PM's annual attendance at Waitangi on our national day could be finished
thread.title_full: The PM's annual attendance at Waitangi on our national day could be finished

author: Jo Moir
title: The PM's annual attendance at Waitangi on our national day could be finished
text:
The PM's annual attendance at Waitangi on our national day could be finished JO MOIR Last updated 14:09, February 3 2017 JASON DORDAY/Stuff.co.nz 
Prime Minister Bill English arrives at the Waitaha Events Centre at the Copthorne Hotel and Resort in Waitangi for the Iwi Chairs Forum ahead of Waitangi Day celebrations. 
It may be years before Prime Minister Bill English returns to Waitangi on our national day after backing the idea of taking the commemorations on tour. 
English is in Waitangi at the annual Iwi Chairs Forum held ahead of Waitangi Day but he turned down an invite to spend the national day here after he was told he couldn't speak at the powhiri. 
Instead English will attend events in Auckland and he says the idea of politicians, iwi and the public travelling to different locations around the country each year was one "worth investigating". JASON DORDAY/FAIRFAX NZ 
Prime Minister Bill English with Maori Affairs Minister Te Ururoa Flavell and his deputy Paula Bennett at the Iwi Chairs Forum at Waitangi. 
"I think if the Government said it was going to move around on Waitangi Day, I don't think there would be any shortage of interest from iwi - they'd be falling over themselves to provide that opportunity for their local communities." 
"I think it's worth investigating because the Treaty was signed in quite a number of places and I suppose the benefit of it would be New Zealanders who don't live in the far North see a bit more of the relevance to their local area," he said.
